overview: This subject continues to build on the skills acquired in Ensemble Studies 1-5, with students expected to take on leadership roles in an ensemble context. Ensemble studies are led by experienced practitioners in the field of contemporary music performance and delivered in practical sessions.

Throughout the subject students will be required to engage in rehearsals, repertoire development, performances and focused group discussions, covering aspects such as interpretation, arrangement, composition, song writing, originality, creativity, balance, interaction, dynamics, tempo, placement, style, rhythm and harmony.
intended learning outcomes: apply advanced composition and improvisation skills to a wide spectrum of music;
apply advanced interpretive and performance skills to original repertoire;
work in a wide variety of musical styles, both individually and as a team member;
contribute an individual style to group performance.

assessments.description: Active contribution to all small ensemble rehearsals. 30 hours (of work required)
16-minute small ensemble performance (group presentation). 20 hours (of work required)
Active contribution to all workshop performances. 10 hours (of work required)
Active contribution to all large ensemble rehearsals and performances as directed. 20 hours (of work required)
Active participation in workshopping songs & compositions (Song Writing /Composition).. 5 hours (of work required)
Hurdle requirement:. Students must attend a minimum of 75% of all scheduled classes and rehearsals as directed.

Semester 1.Contact hours: 67 hours, comprising ten 2-hour weekly small ensemble rehearsals, ten 2-hour weekly ensemble workshops, nine 2-hour weekly large ensemble rehearsals, and six 1.5-hour fortnightly song writing and composition classes.

Semester 2.Contact hours: 82 hours, comprising eleven 2-hour small ensemble rehearsals, twelve 2-hour ensemble workshops, nine 2-hour large ensemble rehearsals, and twelve 1.5-hour song writing and composition classes.

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
